exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crusaders are assembled in the great plaza before the Alhambra's western gates. Eight hundred men stand in ordered ranks beneath the morning sun, white tabards brilliant against the ochre stone of the fortress walls. Their red crosses mark them as something distinct from common soldiers. Captain Fernán Alonso de Robles has organized them into twenty companies of forty men each, mostly veterans who proved themselves at Alcalá, Loja, or the long siege of Málaga.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Every man carries a spear or pike. Half have crossbows; the other half carry swords, maces, war hammers, axes. They are armed, not ceremonial. A baggage train of forty mules carries tents, food supplies for the march to Málaga, the sacred relics in reinforced wooden cases, and iron-bound chests containing the crusade treasury of roughly 315,500 florins. The Guardian Company — twelve picked men including Sergeant García and Corporal Rodrigo — will maintain constant watch over the relics and treasury.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Two hundred horses for mounted sergeants and officers. The rest march on foot. Morale is high — they are tired from two years of campaigning, but they are going to Rome carrying the True Cross and Santiago's bone back to the Holy Father. Don Bernat de Centelles, Alfonso V's ambassador, stands apart with three Aragonese servants and two scribes.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The men are ready. We can march within the hour if you give the word.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Brothers, we are about to embark on a great adventure. One final journey before our task is complete. I have the honour and privilege to travel with you to sacred Rome. When we return, you will be given lands as promised. Your crusader's oaths fulfilled. Every journey is an adventure and I cant tell you exactly what will happen. We travel to Rome, then to Basel. And then we return, ready for a new adventure. But the cameraderie, the friendship and brotherhood lasts for eternity. To Rome!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The roar that erupts from eight hundred throats echoes off the Alhambra's walls. "Roma! Roma!" They take up the cry, pikes and spears thrust skyward. "Deus Vult!" The ancient crusader shout, the same words shouted at Clermont three and a half centuries ago. The white banner with the red cross unfurls as the Guardian Company takes position behind Juan. Captain Fernán raises his hand and the companies begin to move in ordered columns, four abreast.

encounters.recap: Juan II addresses his eight hundred crusaders assembled at the Alhambra and leads them out of Granada toward Málaga, beginning the journey to Rome with relics, treasury, and the proof of the completed Reconquista.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The citizens of Granada — both Christian settlers and Muslim inhabitants — line the streets to watch the departure. Some kneel. Others simply stare. A few Christian women throw flowers. The Muslims watch in silence. The coastal road descends through the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, past villages that were battlegrounds two years ago, now flying Castilian banners. The countryside shows signs of war — burned orchards, a few abandoned farmsteads — but mostly cultivation. The land is healing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By evening of the first day, fifteen miles covered. Giovanni Rossi, the one-handed blacksmith who became a crusader in Barcelona, leads evening prayers. Eight hundred voices join in the Pater Noster. The treasury chests and relic cases remain under constant guard — four men of the Guardian Company, rotating every three hours.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The second day, the mountains give way to coastal plains. The Mediterranean stretches azure to the south. The road improves — this was one of Granada's main routes, maintained since the conquest.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I've seen many armies. Mercenary companies in Italy, the royal hosts of Aragón and France. These men... they're different. It's not just discipline. They believe. His Majesty Alfonso will want to know how you forged this. And Pope Eugenius will see it too. Eight hundred men who completed the Reconquista, marching to return sacred relics and a fortune in florins. The Holy Father has heard many promises from many kings. You're bringing him proof.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The third day: Málaga, sprawling along its bay. The city Juan besieged and took in fourteen days during the summer of 1431. The harbor bristles with masts — and among them, ten Genoese ships. Deep-hulled carracks and galleys capable of the open Mediterranean crossing. A cheer ripples through the ranks.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, should we make camp outside the city tonight and embark tomorrow morning? Or proceed directly to the harbor?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We make camp outside town. Those who want to enter may do so. We send a delegation to announce our arrival. We embark first thing in the morning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crusaders establish camp north of the city walls. Captain Fernán designates three hundred men who may enter the city in rotating groups. Don Bernat de Centelles and Captain Fernán enter the city with an honor guard to announce the arrival to the governor, the harbour master, and confirm arrangements with the Genoese ship captains.

encounters.recap: The crusader army marches three days from Granada to Málaga along the coastal road, passing through conquered territories. Don Bernat observes the crusaders' unique quality. They arrive at Málaga to find ten Genoese ships waiting and make camp outside the city to embark at dawn.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fleet departs Málaga at early afternoon. Ten vessels: six broad-beamed carracks for cargo and troops, four sleeker galleys. The lead carrack flies a banner of Castile's lions and castles quartered with a white cross on red. Loading eight hundred men, two hundred horses, baggage, and treasure took most of the morning.

exchanges.speaker: father_miguel
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I understand you wish to improve your Latin during the voyage. I would be honored to assist, though I confess I lack Fray Hernando's gifts as a teacher.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Days 1-3: The first days go well. The coast of Granada and eastern Iberia slides past. Many crusaders experience seasickness. Father Miguel sets up a small classroom on deck, working through a Latin Psalter with Juan — slow but steady progress on a rolling deck.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Days 4-7: The weather turns as the fleet passes south of the Balearic Islands. Captain Grimaldi curses and starts barking orders. The sky darkens. The ships begin to tack — zigzagging against contrary wind. Most crusaders are now violently ill. The smell below decks becomes unbearable. Latin lessons continue sporadically.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Days 8-12: The contrary winds don't break. Rain lashes the decks. The fleet shelters at Corsica for two days while a fierce storm passes. Marco Tornesi, normally unflappable, is seen leaning over the rail looking thoroughly defeated. Andrea Vescovi, his farm-boy constitution serving him well, helps tend to others. Two horses panic, break legs, and must be put down.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Days 13-14: After the storm breaks and the fleet leaves Corsica, the winds shift favorable. The Italian coast comes into view. But the fleet is very late — a 9-10 day voyage has taken fourteen days. Juan's Latin progress is modest: twenty new phrases, some improved grammar, able to stumble through a few psalms with moderate help.

exchanges.speaker: paolo_grimaldi
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, my apologies for the delay. Worst contrary winds I've seen in April in fifteen years at sea. But we're here, and everything important — men, treasury, relics — is intact. Just two horses lost, and those to panic in the storm.

roll.outcome: Difficult passage. Contrary winds and choppy seas. Many crusaders violently seasick. Forced to shelter at Corsica. Arrive 3-5 days late. Two horses lost. No human casualties but morale affected.

encounters.recap: The Mediterranean crossing from Málaga to Ostia takes fourteen days instead of ten due to severe contrary winds. The fleet shelters at Corsica during a storm, two horses are lost, and the crusaders arrive battered and exhausted but with men, treasury, and relics intact.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fleet limps into Ostia harbor — Rome's port city, fifteen miles from the eternal city. The crusaders are battered, exhausted, and eager for solid ground. Several men literally kiss the dock when they disembark.

exchanges.speaker: harbor_master_ostia
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, we expected you four days ago. There have been inquiries from Rome. Cardinals asking about the delay. Should I send word immediately that you've arrived?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tell me harbour master; what is the situation in Rome? We have travelled from Iberia.

exchanges.speaker: harbor_master_ostia
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... the situation in Rome is, shall we say, complicated. His Holiness Pope Eugenius is under considerable pressure. The Council of Basel refuses to dissolve despite His Holiness ordering it so. They have declared themselves superior to the Holy Father and actually summoned him to appear before them like a common priest. The Emperor Sigismund is on his way to Rome even now. He will be crowned Holy Roman Emperor on the thirty-first of May, five weeks hence.

exchanges.speaker: harbor_master_ostia
exchanges.text: There are other troubles as well. The Duke of Milan's condottieri — Niccolò Piccinino — is making war in the Papal States. And here in Rome itself... the Colonna family. They were close to Pope Martin and His Holiness Pope Eugenius demanded they return lands and castles when he took office. The family is... displeased. There are tensions in the city.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: Is the Holy Father in actual danger?

exchanges.speaker: harbor_master_ostia
exchanges.text: Not immediate danger, no. But Rome is not the peaceful city it should be. Cardinals are divided on the Council question. The streets... well, there are factions. Your Majesty, forgive my boldness, but your arrival may be providential. A king who completed the Reconquista, coming to return sacred relics and a crusade treasury? His Holiness needs allies right now.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Is the road to Rome safe for such a march? Or should we expect... difficulties?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Good question, does the pope control the city gates? We march straight for him. Will we encounter difficulty?

exchanges.speaker: harbor_master_ostia
exchanges.text: His Holiness still controls the gates, yes. Rome has not fallen into open rebellion. The road from Ostia to Rome is safe enough. Fifteen miles, well-traveled. Your eight hundred armed crusaders — I doubt anyone would be foolish enough to interfere with such a force. However, once you enter Rome itself, the Colonna have many supporters. When they see crusaders marching to support Pope Eugenius, there may be words. Perhaps stones thrown from windows. Nothing that threatens your safety, but neither will it be a triumphal procession.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Words and stones we can handle. We've marched through conquered Granada. A few angry Romans won't stop us.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: His Holiness will want to receive you formally. Likely at St. Peter's. Such a public arrival of the Reconquista King with sacred relics — it strengthens his position enormously. The cardinals who support Basel's claims will find it harder to argue the Holy Father lacks divine favor when you kneel before him carrying the True Cross and a crusade treasury.

encounters.recap: At Ostia harbor, the harbour master briefs Juan on Rome's crisis: the Council of Basel challenges papal supremacy, Emperor Sigismund approaches for coronation, the Colonna family is hostile, and Milan's condottieri raid the Papal States. Juan learns his arrival is politically providential for the embattled Pope Eugenius IV.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You can spread the news of our arrival harbour master. Leave the rest to me.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Brothers. What started as a journey to be nothing but a sight seeing journey and a formality to deliver the items and recieve blessing and release from the pope has turned into something serious. The vatican is in danger. I did not wish for this, but it seems the Lord has plans for us in his design once more. We do not know who to trust yet and we do not know the situation exactly. Tell the men what is happening and that we should be on our guard and that we should behave like guests in this foreign land. We disembark, take a rest and then set off towards Rome itself.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Fernán, Marco Tornesi, and the other company commanders gather. The chaplains join as well. Word spreads quickly through the ranks. The crusaders, who had been settling in for rest after the voyage, begin checking their equipment with renewed purpose.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, we've faced worse. Granada, Alcalá, the siege lines at Málaga. These are Roman streets, not battlefields. We'll keep discipline, show respect, but we'll be ready.

exchanges.speaker: marco_tornesi
exchanges.text: I fought in Italy before joining the crusade. Roman mobs can be unpredictable. But they respect strength. Eight hundred armed men marching in formation — that's a language everyone understands.

exchanges.speaker: father_miguel
exchanges.text: We carry the True Cross. Whatever happens, God's hand is in this. I'll make sure the men understand — we're guests, yes, but we're also witnesses. The Holy Father needs to see that Castile stands with him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By evening, the crusaders have disembarked. The horses are watered and fed. The treasury chests and relic cases are secured under triple guard. The men eat a simple meal, check their equipment one final time, and settle in for a few hours of rest. Tomorrow morning, they march to Rome.

encounters.recap: Learning of Rome's crisis, Juan calls his commanders together and decides to march on Rome the next morning. He orders the men to stay on guard and behave as guests in a foreign land. The crusaders prepare for what may be more than a ceremonial visit.

encounters.location: Rome, Via Ostiensis to St. Peter's

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crusaders form up as the sun rises over Ostia. Eight hundred men in white tabards, pikes and spears at the ready. The Guardian Company surrounds the treasury and relic carts. The column stretches nearly half a mile along the Via Ostiensis — the ancient Roman road, fifteen miles of paved stone worn smooth by centuries.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The first few miles are quiet. Farmers stop work to watch. A few merchants pull their carts aside. As they draw closer to Rome, the division becomes visible. A group of forty people beneath a Colonna family banner watch in complete silence — arms crossed, faces hard. One young noble spits on the ground. Two hundred yards further, a small church with sixty people gathered outside — clerics, monks, common folk waving and calling blessings. An elderly priest holds up a crucifix, tears streaming. "Deus Vult!" they shout. "Viva il Papa!"

exchanges.speaker: marco_tornesi
exchanges.text: Like I said — divided city. Those Colonna supporters? They're not going to cheer for anyone who strengthens the Pope.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: At the Porta San Paolo, papal guards stand at attention. A papal administrator waits with an escort, bowing deeply and welcoming Juan in the name of Pope Eugenius IV. Inside, Trastevere erupts in cheers — streets packed, flowers from balconies, old women weeping, children running alongside. Giovanni Rossi, carrying the white banner, his scarred face streaming with tears, begins singing the Te Deum. Hundreds of Roman voices join him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then across a bridge over the Tiber, the atmosphere changes completely. Colonna territory — silent, shops shuttered, windows closed. Colonna retainers stand in groups, hands on sword hilts. A stone cracks off the cobblestones near the column, then another. Captain Fernán's hand goes to his sword. The crusaders tighten formation. The stone-throwing stops — they don't want open confrontation, just to make their position known.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Approaching St. Peter's, the streets fill again — thousands gathered. The reception is warm but measured. A group of two dozen cardinals in red robes waits at the steps. Cardinal Giordano Orsini stands at their head. Behind them, at the top of the great steps, Pope Eugenius IV himself — tall, thin, wearing the papal tiara and white robes.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Welcome to Rome. You arrive at a complicated moment. His Holiness will receive you formally, but first... the divisions you saw in the streets — they are real. The Colonna family controls perhaps a third of the city's military strength. The Council of Basel has supporters even among the cardinals here. Your arrival is both blessing and complication. Some see it as foreign interference in Roman affairs. Others see it as divine providence.

roll.outcome: Mixed reception — divided city. Some quarters cheer with flowers and kneeling as relics pass. Other quarters silence, shuttered windows, occasional stones thrown. Clear factional divide visible throughout the march.

encounters.recap: The crusaders march fifteen miles from Ostia to Rome, entering through the Porta San Paolo. The city is visibly divided: Trastevere erupts in cheers while Colonna territory is silent and hostile, with stones thrown. They arrive at St. Peter's to find Pope Eugenius waiting on the steps with two dozen cardinals.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Fernán organizes the presentation. The Guardian Company brings forward the items: the gold reliquary with the True Cross fragment sealed in white silk; the silver reliquary holding Santiago's bone; the original crusade bull Inter Cetera Divinae; Sultan Yusuf IV's formal renunciation document; Archbishop Alonso de Toledo's statement on Granada's Christianization; the battle-worn white banner with its red cross; three iron-bound chests containing approximately 315,500 florins with the complete 47-page accounting.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan's commanders gather: Captain Fernán, Marco Tornesi, Andrea Vescovi, Giovanni Rossi, Brother Guillem, Father Miguel, and several company captains. Fifteen men total. Don Bernat de Centelles positions himself with the party. The rest of the crusaders remain in formation in the plaza.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The great steps of St. Peter's rise before them. At the top, Pope Eugenius IV stands flanked by thirty cardinals. Thousands of Romans watch from the plaza. Cardinal Orsini murmurs protocol as they ascend: present the relics first, then documents, then treasury.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Juan II, King of Castile and León, Conqueror of Granada, you are most welcome to Rome.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Castille stands ready to serve the Church of Christ, as always father. Our swords are yours to command. The church placed great trust in me when it granted me crusade. I have come so that the vatican can judge our efforts and release us from our duty and oath.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan kneels and kisses the Fisherman's Ring. Pope Eugenius embraces him — an unusually personal gesture. His thin face works with emotion.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Juan of Castile. Three years ago, you knelt before Pope Martin in this very city. You offered everything to God — stripped naked before the Vicar of Christ, holding nothing back. Pope Martin wept that day. He granted you authority to crusade against Granada, and he wept because he saw something in you that moved him deeply. He did not live to see this day. But if he watches from Heaven, he sees his judgment vindicated.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Let all witness what stands before us. The Reconquista — seven centuries of struggle — is complete. The sacred relics entrusted to this king return to Rome. The crusade treasury returns with accounting so thorough that it would satisfy the most demanding merchant in Christendom. The Emirate of Granada, which threatened Christian Europe since the eighth century, has surrendered. Its capital flies the cross of Christ.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: This is what papal authority, rightly exercised and faithfully obeyed, can accomplish. When the Church acts through Peter's successor with pure intention, when Christian kings submit to that authority with humble hearts, God grants victory.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Several cardinals who support Basel look distinctly uncomfortable. Cardinal Orsini is openly weeping. The crowd in the plaza erupts: "Deus Vult! Christus Vincit!"

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: King Juan, your crusade oath is fulfilled. The Church releases you from your obligation with honor, with gratitude, and with blessing. Castile has kept faith. You have kept faith. But I sense you did not travel from Granada merely to be released from an oath. We have much to discuss — matters that require careful consideration and private counsel.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Let it be proclaimed throughout Christendom: the Reconquista is complete. King Juan II of Castile has fulfilled his crusade oath with such honor that it stands as witness to all Christian monarchs of what can be accomplished when papal authority and royal fidelity work in harmony.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope raises his hands toward the eight hundred crusaders in the plaza. He blesses them, releasing them from their crusade oaths with honor. Many veterans — of Alcalá, Loja, Málaga, the long siege of Granada — drop to their knees. Giovanni Rossi is openly sobbing. Marco Tornesi stands rigid at attention but his shoulders are shaking.

roll.outcome: Deeply grateful, politically aware. Pope personally and genuinely moved. Public release from oath with warmth. Uses Juan's success as argument for papal authority against Basel. Private audience clearly offered. Petitions will be seriously considered.

encounters.recap: At St. Peter's, Juan presents the sacred relics, Sultan's surrender, crusade treasury, and all documents to Pope Eugenius IV. The Pope publicly releases Juan from his crusade oath with high honor, uses the occasion to make a pointed case for papal authority against the Council of Basel, and signals a private audience to discuss Juan's petitions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The group moves through St. Peter's into the papal apartments — surprisingly austere. A wooden table, several chairs, a crucifix on the wall, and little else. Present: Pope Eugenius IV, now without the papal tiara, looking exhausted; Cardinal Giordano Orsini; and Bishop Carrera serving as recorder. Juan's commanders remain outside with the relics and treasury under guard.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Let us speak plainly. The public ceremony was necessary — Rome needed to see your arrival. But now we can speak as men facing difficult circumstances rather than as pontiff and king performing for an audience.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the situation is dire. Cardinal Cesarini — my colleague, a good man — is at Basel right now presiding over the council. He opened it as papal legate in 1431, but when His Holiness tried to dissolve it, Cesarini sided with the council. He's not our enemy — he wants reform — but he believes the council has supreme authority over the Pope.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Cesarini won't return my letters. He thinks I'm destroying the Church by resisting Basel's claims. He doesn't understand — or won't understand — that what they demand would make every pope subject to every council's whims.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: The theological question is profound. Does supreme authority rest with Peter's successor, or with the assembled bishops in council? It's not merely about power — it's about the very nature of how Christ structured His Church. Emperor Sigismund has been trying to mediate. He came to Rome, was crowned Holy Roman Emperor. He convinced both sides to compromise — His Holiness acknowledged Basel as ecumenical, withdrew the dissolution. Basel stopped pressing their most extreme claims. But it's an unstable peace.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And while we debate theology, practical realities press. The Colonna family controls much of Rome. They're angry I demanded return of properties Martin granted them. Milan's condottieri raid the Papal States. Florence and Venice look to me for support against Milan, but that creates more enemies. You saw it in the streets — the city is divided.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: Your arrival changes the equation, whether you intended it or not. The Basel faction claims papal authority has failed. And then you arrive — the young king who received papal crusade authority three years ago — bearing proof that papal authority, properly exercised, can accomplish miracles.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You came to return relics and be released from your crusade oath. But you also brought petitions. The Military Orders — you want permanent royal control. King Alfonso's Naples claim — you want papal support. I am inclined to grant what you ask. You've earned it. Castile has earned it. But we must discuss how to manage the political implications.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Holy father, I am a king and a soldier in the employ of Jezus Christ. Church authority stands absolute for me. It has to, let me explain. Christian morals guide us, they set me and my people on the right path. It's laws bring resolution and it's monestaries are centres of development and learning. It unites us and lets us fight for a higher purpose. I have committed my life to being a good Christian and will die defending it and it's institutions.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Which is exactly why any accusations of sins by the clergy or even actual sins by church members are terrible. And it makes me feel helpless as well. Helpless because I have no defence against it. I have placed all my trust and faith into the church and I refuse to believe that such a thing is even possible.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The church of Rome is a shining beacon, a light coming straight from God's kingdom. We have built it up to great hights. Should we lose it... I cannot even imagine that. I would be nothing without the church, without my faith. I will not allow thought of the church to be somehow impure to enter my mind. Instead, I fight for the kingdom of God's image. As the world should be.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Me and my bishops in Castille have thought long and hard about what to do and eventually we decided to send a delegation to Basel. We did so without giving thought to the current wars and alliances. Instead we motivated our attendance purelly based on theological grounds and came to the conclusion that it was also Rome's will that the council be held. I remind you that I have pledged my sword if need be to fight the Hussites in Bohemia should we fail to come together like christians.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But please father, understand the impossible position I find myself in when I witness sins in the church itself. Please protect me from ever making an impossible choice.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan kneels before the Pope, voice breaking with emotion. The room is utterly silent. Cardinal Orsini has tears in his eyes. Bishop Carrera has stopped taking notes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pope Eugenius slowly removes the papal tiara from his head and sets it on the table. He asks Cardinal Orsini and Bishop Carrera to leave. Alone with Juan, he kneels beside him — not before him, but beside him, as one man to another.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: I'm going to tell you something I've told no one. When the Council of Basel summoned me — demanded that I, the successor of Peter, appear before them like a common priest — I didn't just question whether I was right to resist. I questioned everything. I asked God: Have I failed so completely that You no longer want me as Your Vicar? Should I submit to Basel because perhaps councils should be supreme if popes can fail this badly?

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: For three years I've fought. The Colonna, Basel, Milan's armies, cardinals who desert me. And every day I ask myself: Am I defending Christ's Church, or am I defending my own pride? Is papal authority divine, or is it just my refusal to admit I'm wrong?

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: I prayed for a sign. Any sign. That God still wanted papal authority to exist. That someone still believed the Church could be what Christ intended. And then you arrived. The young king who completed the Reconquista under papal authority. Who returns the sacred relics with perfect honor. Who sends his delegation to Basel because of theology, not politics.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You ask me to protect you from impossible choices. I cannot. The corruption you fear exists. Simony, concubinage, cardinals who scheme, all of it. I cannot promise you the pure Church you need to believe in. But you've given me something more precious than gold or armies. You've reminded me why the impossible choice matters.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Pope Martin saw it in you three years ago. That's why he wept when you offered everything. He knew the world would try to destroy that innocence. But you kept it. Through seven hundred battles, through years of war — you kept it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope stands, helps Juan to his feet. His face is transformed — the crushing doubt and exhaustion still present, but underneath: hope. Determination.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: The Military Orders belong to you. The crown that completed the Reconquista under papal authority deserves permanent control. No future pope can revoke it. Alfonso's Naples claim — I will support it strongly, publicly. We will write to every Christian monarch explaining why Castile proved papal authority works.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You asked me to protect your faith. I cannot make the Church pure. But I can promise you this: you will not face impossible choices alone. When Basel forces you to choose between reform and authority, we will face it together. You are not just our ally in politics — you are our conscience in faith.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope replaces the papal tiara, strides to the door, and calls Cardinal Orsini and Bishop Carrera back in. His voice fills the chamber with certainty it hasn't held in years. He orders word sent to loyal cardinals — the King of Castile stands with Rome, not from politics, but from faith.

roll.outcome: Breakthrough moment — mutual recognition. Pope removes tiara, dismisses attendants, confesses his private doubts to Juan alone. Forms deep personal bond. All petitions granted. Pope sees Juan as answer to his prayers for a sign. Strong alliance proclaimed.

encounters.recap: In private chambers, Juan passionately declares his absolute faith in Church authority and begs the Pope to protect him from witnessing corruption. Profoundly moved, Eugenius removes his tiara, dismisses his attendants, and confesses his own crisis of faith to Juan alone. The two form a deep spiritual bond. The Pope grants the Military Orders to Castile permanently, pledges support for Alfonso's Naples claim, and declares Juan his conscience in faith.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: One hour later, twenty-three cardinals loyal to Pope Eugenius are assembled in the formal audience chamber. Cardinal Orsini stands at the Pope's right hand. Juan stands before them.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We, Eugenius, servant of the servants of God, do hereby decree and proclaim: First, that His Majesty King Juan II of Castile is released from his crusade oath with the highest honors. His service stands as example to all Christian monarchs. Second, that the Military Orders of Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara shall henceforth belong under perpetual royal control of the Crown of Castile, binding all future popes. Third, that we support and endorse the claim of King Alfonso V of Aragón to the Kingdom of Naples against all challengers. Fourth, that when His Majesty travels to Basel, he speaks with our blessing and carries our confidence.

exchanges.speaker: pope_eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: We have fought alone for three years. We fight no longer alone. Castile stands with Rome. Rome stands with Castile. Let all Christendom witness this alliance, forged not in politics but in shared faith.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cardinals burst into genuine, enthusiastic applause. Cardinal Orsini is weeping again. Several others wipe their eyes.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_orsini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, what happened in that private chamber... His Holiness is transformed. We haven't seen him speak with such certainty since his election. You gave him something he desperately needed. This will create reactions. The Basel-supporting cardinals will report this immediately. The Colonna will see a powerful foreign ally. Emperor Sigismund arrives in five weeks. But for now, let us simply be grateful. The Holy Father needed hope. You gave it to him.

encounters.recap: Pope Eugenius IV formally decrees before twenty-three cardinals: Juan is released from his crusade oath with highest honors; the Military Orders of Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara are granted to the Crown of Castile in perpetuity; Alfonso V's Naples claim is endorsed; and Juan is blessed to speak at Basel with papal confidence.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: That evening, the crusaders are quartered throughout Vatican properties and nearby monasteries. The treasury and relics are secured in Vatican vaults. Don Bernat de Centelles finds Juan as evening falls.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, word of today's events is spreading through Rome like wildfire. The proclamations about the Military Orders and Naples support — King Alfonso will be extremely pleased. But there's more happening beneath the surface. The Romans are calling you 'Il Re Crociato' — the Crusader King. Some see your arrival as providential. Others whisper that a Spanish king now controls the papacy through spiritual manipulation.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: The Colonna family has been quiet today. Too quiet. They control significant military force in Rome. Your eight hundred crusaders are formidable, but the Colonna have thousands of retainers if they choose to mobilize. And Basel will hear about this within days. Cardinal Cesarini presiding over the Council, your delegation arguing there, and now the Pope proclaiming you speak with his blessing — that changes the entire dynamic.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Outside the window, Rome stretches into twilight. Church bells mark evening prayers. Somewhere in this ancient city, factions are reacting, calculating their responses, deciding whether Juan is ally or threat. Tomorrow the Pope wants to discuss practical matters — the journey to Basel, the timing, what to say to the Council fathers. The Reconquista is complete. The crusade oath is fulfilled. The Military Orders belong to Castile forever. Alfonso's Naples claim has papal support. But Juan's role in the Church's great crisis is just beginning.

encounters.recap: Don Bernat de Centelles briefs Juan on the political fallout of the day's events. Rome calls him 'Il Re Crociato.' The Colonna are ominously quiet, Basel will hear within days, and factions across the city recalculate. Juan's formal mission is complete, but his entanglement in the papal-conciliar crisis has only just begun.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The private chamber is surprisingly modest. No throne, no ceremonial trappings—just a table set for three, wine already poured, and a fire crackling against the spring chill. Pope Eugenius IV sits in simple white robes, the papal tiara nowhere in sight. Cardinal Giordano Orsini stands by the window.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Please, sit. Tonight we speak not as Pope and King, but as brothers facing a common crisis.

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: The couriers departed for Basel this morning. Cardinal Cesarini will have word of yesterday's events within eight days. Perhaps less if the weather holds. Which means we have very little time to prepare you for what awaits.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You asked yesterday how you could serve the Church. Tonight, I will tell you honestly what I need. But first, you must understand what you're walking into. Basel is not a council seeking truth through prayer and contemplation. It is a battlefield where the soul of the Church hangs in the balance. And I have sent you—knowingly, deliberately—into the center of that war.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope takes the document Juan's bishops prepared, reading in silence. Cardinal Orsini leans over to read alongside him. Finally, the Pope sets the parchment down, his hand trembling slightly.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You would grant the chalice to the laity. After we burned Jan Hus at Constance for teaching precisely this doctrine. After five crusades and forty thousand Christian deaths defending the Church's position. You understand what this means? That we were wrong. That Hus was right. That all those deaths were... for nothing.

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I see the strategic wisdom here. The Bohemian property line is exactly what we need—a principled position that distinguishes genuine reform from rewarding theft. This could break the deadlock. The moderate faction at Basel has been seeking precisely such a distinction.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But the theological concessions... Communion in both kinds. Vernacular preaching. These are not small matters. Every conservative cardinal in Rome will see this as capitulation. As validating heresy through military success. They will say: 'Get an army, fight some crusades, and eventually the Church admits you were right.' What precedent does that set?

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: Holy Father, with respect—that ship has sailed. Basel is already negotiating the Compacts. Cardinal Cesarini himself supports communion in both kinds. The question is not whether these concessions will be made, but whether they will be made through reconciliation or through schism.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And if through schism? If Basel declares these reforms over my objection, establishes them by conciliar authority alone, what then? Do I accept their supremacy? Do I split the Church defending a practice that even you admit needs reform?

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: The Castilian position offers a third path. Support the reforms on their theological merits. Frame them not as concessions to heresy, but as return to apostolic practice that the Church should have made generations ago. Distinguish these genuine reforms from Bohemian property theft, which remains condemned. Make Basel's theological victory also Rome's theological victory.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And the question of authority? 'Support papal supremacy in its proper sphere. Support conciliar authority in its proper sphere.' Your Majesty, do you understand what you're proposing? That neither Pope nor Council is absolutely supreme? That the very question Basel and Rome are fighting over should simply... remain unresolved?

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: It's actually rather brilliant. Refuse to take sides in the constitutional question while taking clear positions on the practical reforms. Basel cannot accuse Castile of blind papalism—you support reforms they want. Rome cannot accuse Castile of conciliarism—you draw hard lines on Church property and rebellion.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Or both sides see Castile as fence-sitting. I need to understand your thinking, Your Majesty. Yesterday you wept, begging me to preserve your faith in the Church's purity. Today you present positions that acknowledge the Church was wrong on matters of theology for decades. How do you reconcile these things? How do you maintain your faith while accepting that the Church has erred?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Holy Father, these positions are what the bishops drafted after discussing these matters on their theological merits. We have not taken into account any previous action of the Church, or that these positions would imply the Church was wrong previously. From my perspective, five failed crusades against Bohemia is a tragedy in itself. Christians fighting Christians over matters of theology that could have been discussed in council.

encounters.recap: Pope Eugenius IV and Cardinal Orsini review the Castilian theological positions on Hussite reforms, finding the distinction between genuine reform and Bohemian property theft strategically powerful but questioning the theological implications.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Will the Holy Father allow me an innocent question? Would you accompany me to Basel and be part of the council? My eight hundred crusaders and I could provide security to and during the council, should you wish it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope's wine cup freezes halfway to his lips. He sets it down with exaggerated care. Cardinal Orsini has gone completely still.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I need you to understand something with absolute clarity. For three years, the Council of Basel has claimed supremacy over the papacy. They have summoned me—the successor of Peter—to appear before them like a criminal facing magistrates. I have refused. Not from pride, but from principle. Because if I go to Basel in response to their summons, then the question is answered. Forever. Papal authority becomes subordinate to conciliar authority.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You offer me eight hundred crusaders for protection. Do you understand what that would mean? That the Pope requires armed escort to attend a church council? That military force determines where the Vicar of Christ may or may not go?

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the radicals at Basel would proclaim it from every pulpit in Christendom: 'We summoned the Pope. He resisted for three years. But we persisted, and finally he came with an army at his back, admitting through his actions that he fears the Council's judgment.'

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And in Rome? The Colonna family would see my departure as abandonment. Milan's condottieri are raiding the Papal States even now. If I leave Rome, this city falls. Your innocence is a gift, Your Majesty. But innocence without understanding is dangerous. Good intentions paired with eight hundred swords do not solve constitutional crises. They create martyrs and precedents that bind the Church for generations.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But your offer to bring me to Basel with military escort shows you do not yet understand the political realities those positions must navigate.

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, Basel must be faced—but not by the Pope submitting to their summons. It must be faced by a king whose crusade victory gives him moral authority independent of the constitutional question.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You can go to Basel. You should go to Basel. But not as my escort. Not as my protector. As an independent Christian monarch whose completion of the Reconquista gives you the standing to speak truth to both sides. Do you understand now why your attendance at Basel must be yours alone?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course, Holy Father. Thank you for explaining it to me. I was merely inquiring about the situation, not seeking to pressure your person in any direction. I will go to Basel and try to resolve the issues. And I think I am indeed in a good position to do so. As crusader king, I can make the distinction between true reform and giving in to rebellion. No one can be benefitting monetarily from this reform.

encounters.recap: Juan naively proposes the Pope attend Basel under crusader escort; the Pope firmly rejects this as politically catastrophic but redirects Juan to attend as an independent Christian monarch with moral authority from the Reconquista.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tension in the Pope's shoulders eases. Cardinal Orsini and the Pope discuss the strategic position Juan holds—supporting reforms Basel wants while drawing absolute lines Rome needs.

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: The radicals at Basel will test you immediately. They will ask: Do you support conciliar supremacy? They will demand you choose. What will you say?

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And the moderates will seek to use you. How will you maintain independence when every faction wants to claim you as their champion?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It seems those wanting for conciliar supremacy are a significant faction. We must ask ourselves WHY they feel this way. Speaking as someone outside church hierarchy, I think I might understand. It is the helplessness I mentioned. They cannot oppose corruption in the Church without also opposing papal authority. If we adopt the measures my bishops propose, we take away their primary concern.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And what I cannot stand are nobles—Bohemian nobles—who see these reforms as a way to enrich themselves. I will expose these vultures for what they are. Leave that to me, Father. God willing we can end the Hussite heresy and stop Christian on Christian wars and let us focus on the real threat: The Eastern church and stopping the Ottomans.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: If my cousin and ally Alfonso can secure Naples, it gives me the real means to help our brothers in Constantinople and bring the sword against the Ottomans. I would like to talk with the Byzantine delegation and hear how they feel about the situation. I must be careful before suggesting anything like reunion of both churches, but I have the real means to help them. We have the large crusade treasury. I have the fleet. Should the Church command me to, I can realistically fight the Ottomans.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope's eyes widen. He leans forward, and something kindles in his expression—the first genuine hope Juan has seen since arriving in Rome.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You're proposing to redirect Christendom's energy. Stop fighting ourselves—Hussites, conciliar disputes, papal-imperial struggles—and face the actual threat. Constantinople. The Ottomans. And you have the means.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: But I must ensure you understand the obstacles before you. First—the Filioque. The Orthodox Church rejected the Western addition to the Nicene Creed four centuries ago. Any reunion requires resolving this. Second, the Greeks are desperate but proud. They suspect any Western help comes with chains attached.

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: Third, logistics. János Hunyadi estimated thirty-five to forty thousand professional soldiers needed to drive the Ottomans from Europe. The Ottomans are not Granada.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: And yet... what if he can actually do it? Your Majesty, I am inspired by this vision. Genuinely. But I need to know—when you meet the Byzantine delegation, what will you actually offer them? And what will you require in return?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: First things first. And let me be completely honest. I place my faith and my trust completely and utterly in the Church and in the Vatican. There is one Church of Christianity and this is the Catholic Church. There should be no doubt by anyone who can command me or Castile.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The Greeks are proud, sure. But why does this theological debate start really? Is it purely because of theological grounds or are there... worldly concerns as well?

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: An honest question deserves an honest answer. And the honest answer is... both. The Filioque clause itself is genuine theology. But the timing of the schism? Politics. Constantinople was the seat of the Roman Empire. Why should the Bishop of Rome command the Patriarch of Constantinople?

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You see the knot. Worldly concerns and theological principle are woven together. The Greeks need our swords. We need their recognition of our authority. Neither side trusts the other's motives.

encounters.recap: Juan presents an inspired vision of ending Hussite heresy through genuine reform, exposing Bohemian noble theft, and redirecting Christendom against the Ottoman threat, genuinely inspiring the Pope while prompting serious discussion of the theological and logistical obstacles ahead.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We cannot make the Byzantines trust us by talking about them here in Rome. Trust comes slowly and requires us to trust them first. The way I see it, we have some genuine arguments to end the Hussite heresy and bring them back into the Catholic fold. To wrap it up, I will discipline any nobles who will not return church lands and property. Then, I will seek to channel our energy towards the Ottoman threat and helping the Byzantines. I will need to hear from and talk to their delegation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope's enthusiasm tempers. He sets down his wine cup and fixes Juan with a penetrating look.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I appreciate the clarity of your thinking. A sequence. First Hussites, then Ottomans. But I must ask you some difficult questions about what each of those steps actually entails.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: You say you will 'discipline nobles who will not return church lands.' You are proposing military intervention in Bohemia. Against nobles who have defeated five papal crusades. Jan Žižka never lost a battle. What makes you believe your army would fare differently?

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Second, you say 'end the Hussite heresy and bring them back into the Catholic fold.' The Church has been attempting this since 1415. Nothing has worked. Do you truly believe that offering communion in both kinds will suddenly resolve eighteen years of warfare?

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: And the timeline. You speak of helping the Byzantines after resolving the Hussite question. Your Majesty, Constantinople may not have years. The Byzantine delegation at Basel is desperate now.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: I do not say these things to discourage you. Your vision yesterday inspired me. But visions must be grounded in reality. Bohemia is not Iberia. How do you propose to deploy your assets? What is your actual plan?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Fathers, right now, all I can declare is my intentions. And I apologize if I suggest these issues are easy. They are not. Right now, I cannot march my armies to Bohemia. Any plan I make right now can be thrown out the moment I meet with the Emperor. His support for any campaign is crucial.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I should isolate the support for the nobles first. Right now, they are seen as heroes. Changing their perception from that to money grabbing thieves changes their position drastically. All these things may be achieved without marching one mile towards Bohemia. Just the threat, the possibility that I might, could return lands to the Church without one sword being drawn.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes a sequential strategy of resolving the Hussite conflict before aiding Constantinople, but the Pope probes hard on the feasibility of each step, demanding specifics about military enforcement and timelines.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I do not ask you to trust my plan, but to trust me to advance our position in the council. I do not know what comes first. If and when I can help the Byzantines. I first must listen to them and go from there. Finally, I must confess that I am bound to a promise and I always keep my promises. My wife is expecting and I promised to be by her side during delivery. I can leave Rome, meet with the Emperor on the way if God permits, attend the Basel council and contribute as best I can, and then return home.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Excuse me for thinking like I am invincible. I am not. Maybe the crusade has made me bold and overly confident. I will guard my soul against pride. I can only promise my best effort.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Pope's expression transforms. He sits back in his chair, and something releases in his face—tension Juan hadn't realized was there.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: There. There is the man I hoped you would be. You declared your intentions while admitting you cannot control the outcomes. You acknowledged your limitations. And then you revealed that you are bound by a promise to your pregnant wife. That despite visions of crusades and councils, you will return home to stand beside Isabel when she needs you.

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: That, Your Majesty, is not the mark of a glory-seeker. That is the mark of a faithful man.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Very well. Let us speak not of what you must do, but of what we can offer you. First, timing. Emperor Sigismund arrives in Rome on May thirty-first. Second, the Byzantine delegation. Third, letters. I will provide you with personal correspondence to Cardinal Cesarini, to the Byzantine delegation, to the key moderate voices at Basel. And most importantly—my trust. I do. Completely.

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: And when you must leave for Isabel—leave. No one can fault a husband keeping faith with his wife during her travail. Your departure will not undermine your position. If anything, it reinforces who you are.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think it is best I leave for Basel and meet the Byzantine delegation there and meet the Emperor on the road while travelling. I would rather not wait for him to arrive here in five weeks.

exchanges.speaker: giordano_orsini
exchanges.text: Wise. Five weeks waiting in Rome accomplishes nothing. The route from Rome to Basel is approximately five weeks total.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: I will prepare letters tonight. And your eight hundred crusaders? Do they all accompany you?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will take fifty crusaders with me in order to travel faster. The rest can stay here for a while. Should their presence hurt your position, they can leave. If their presence can stabilize Rome, they can stay. Either way, they will return to Granada, receive their land titles and then choose if they want to continue to serve me, or live a peaceful life.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: One final matter. When you reach Basel and meet the Byzantine delegation—what is the first thing you wish to understand from them?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: When I meet the Byzantines, I will listen first. Listen to what their concerns are, their fears. I am a military commander so I am interested in what military assets they have, but I think it is much more important for me to learn their fears first. How afraid are they that any new help will plunder Constantinople again? Those would be the most important subject to discuss.

exchanges.speaker: eugenius_iv
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you have just demonstrated more wisdom about the Greek situation than most of my cardinals possess. Listen to them. Truly listen. And when they speak of the Fourth Crusade, do not defend it. Acknowledge that Christians failed Christians catastrophically.

encounters.recap: Juan reveals his limitations and promise to return to his pregnant wife, profoundly moving the Pope, who shifts from testing to full partnership and offers letters of introduction, strategic counsel, and complete trust for Juan's journey to Basel.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan departs Rome with fifty crusaders, traveling through Tuscany, past Florence, through Bologna, into the Alpine foothills. The journey proves arduous but the Pope's letters of safe conduct ensure hospitality. Brother Guillem leads evening prayers that keep the men's spirits high despite long days in the saddle. They reach Trent in the shadow of the Dolomites.

encounters.recap: Juan and fifty crusaders depart Rome and travel north through Italy toward Basel, carrying papal letters of introduction and safe conduct.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A rider bursts into the common room where Juan is eating. He found the Emperor's party four days south, making for Verona. Sigismund sends a detailed letter.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Greetings from the road... I regret I cannot delay my journey to Rome... Your intention to address the Hussite question interests me greatly. If you would hear my thoughts, know this: The Bohemian nobles are not monolithic... I am told you propose military enforcement if diplomacy fails. With respect, Your Majesty—you do not know what you propose... I will be at Basel after my Roman coronation. Meet with me there.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text:
To my brother in Christian arms, Emperor Sigismund.

Reading your letter makes me regret meeting you in person even more, for I feel we are like-minded and I sense we can achieve much together. A meeting will have to wait, you have a coronation, I have a pregnant wife. Both events that require our personal attention.

You are not the first to warn me against Hussite military capabilities. A warning I take very seriously and will not go unheeded. My greatest fear is that my commitment will actually hurt the resolution of the conflict. Personally, nobles profiting from this rebellion goes against every grain of moral and virtue that I hold dear.

A general only makes a battleplan when he arrives on the battlefield. Without knowing the battlefield yet, I cannot tell you how I will win should I even have to march against them. I am merely expressing my willingness to fight injustice, especially when the Church is involved.

Should the moment arrive when you feel our interests align that you would allow me and my armies free passage, this would overcome an important hurdle for me and would signal your support for me. I place no expectation on this request and look forward to meeting you personally, God willing in good health and circumstance.

I congratulate you with your coronation and wish you all the best.

Juan II of Castile.

encounters.recap: Juan's riders intercept Emperor Sigismund near Verona, resulting in a substantive letter exchange where the Emperor offers detailed counsel on Bohemia and promises to seek Juan out personally at Basel.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Five days later, outside Zurich, the rider finds Juan again with the Emperor's reply. It is written in Sigismund's own hand.

exchanges.speaker: sigismund
exchanges.text: Juan— I dispense with formalities... You are different. Perhaps it is that you place no expectation on your request... I will not grant you blanket permission to march through the Empire... But I tell you this: if your proposals at Basel prove sound... then we will discuss specifics... Prove to me at Basel that you are the man your letters suggest. I will seek you out personally. Your brother in Christ and perhaps in purpose, Sigismund. P.S. Congratulate your wife for me.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, that is... that is not a letter from an emperor to a foreign king. That is a letter from a soldier to a soldier.

encounters.recap: Emperor Sigismund sends a remarkably personal reply recognizing Juan as a potential true ally, offering conditional support and promising to seek him out at Basel for substantive strategic discussions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan arrives at Basel. The city is crowded with delegations. Abbott Rodrigo and Bishop Alfonso greet him, but the Byzantine delegation (Bessarion and Isidore) is also waiting at the gates.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: Your Majesty King Juan of Castile. I am Metropolitan Bessarion of Nicaea. My colleague is Isidore, Metropolitan of Kiev and All Rus. We have heard many Western kings speak of helping Constantinople. We have seen fewer actually understand what that help would mean—for us.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: The last time Western crusaders came to 'help' us, they burned our libraries and stole our relics. Forgive us if we approach your offer with... caution.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: Why are you here, King of Castile? What do you want from Constantinople? And what price would your help carry?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You surprise me, these matters are not to be discussed in the presence of cobblestones. If you would honour me by visiting me and my company after we have settled in, I am more than able to explore how I can be of assistance to the ancient Roman city.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan walks to a central space and addresses the gathered crowd.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I thank the city of Basel for their hospitality. When a great host of Christians gather, it inspires the soul with what is possible. I am interested to hear from all those interested in an audience. But please allow me and my company some time to settle in. Contact one of my commanders and we can arrange a meeting.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The reception is neutral. Juan points to his commanders. As the crowd disperses, he speaks to Brother Guillem.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Brother Guillem, please go after them and make sure they understand that I would like to meet with them as soon as possible. But that these discussions should be held privately, not in the open.

encounters.recap: Juan arrives at Basel to a neutral reception; the Byzantine delegation greets him at the gates with urgent questions, but Juan deflects to private meetings, making no enemies but no friends in his cautious public debut.

exchanges.speaker: hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: Speak freely. What burdens your soul? What sins weigh upon you?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Forgive me Father for I have sinned. I have sinned many times in terms of pride, thinking myself better than the simple soul that I am. But what burdens me the most is my ambition as a king. I have secured the kingdom of Naples through alliance with Aragon, knowing full well that I have claims on this kingdom as well through my inheritance claim on Aragon. I tell myself that this is for the Christian cause, but I know that a part of me also just wants this kingdom for myself.

exchanges.speaker: hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: So I ask again: When you think of Naples... do you see ships carrying crusaders to Constantinople? Or do you see a crown for your head?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Honestly? I see crusaders aiding Constantinople. But I also see... not really a crown on my head, but Naples being part of what we have discussed so often. Naples being part of God's kingdom on earth. An inspiring vision. I want to reform Naples as I am reforming Castile. Is that selfish, Father?

exchanges.speaker: hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: The line between righteous ambition and sinful pride is not a wall—it is a rope bridge over an abyss... This is why I give you this penance: Before you make any major decision at this Council, sit in silence for one hour and ask yourself one question: 'What if I am wrong?'

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I can and I will, Father. Now, Isabel is with child again. I pressed for this, as the kingdom needs an heir. But she was so afraid after last time. What if my choice will lead to her death, Father?

exchanges.speaker: hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: You pressed for this? Did you command her as king? Did you persuade her as husband? Or did you decide together?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We prayed together and she overcame her fear. I did not force her at all, but I know that we are not equals. She is very dutiful. Even me gently asking her might as well feel like a command for her.

exchanges.speaker: hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: You understand the nature of power better than most kings... If Isabel dies in childbed, you will carry that grief for the rest of your life. And you should.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Whatever happens next, I will carry the consequences. And I know there is no other way. It must be done. My vision for God's kingdom demands it, Father. It must be done.

exchanges.speaker: hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: Stop. Do you hear the danger in those words? 'It must be done.' Must it? Says who? You? Has God appeared to you... or have you decided what God's kingdom requires and called that decision divine?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I stand up as well. It must be done, Father. I command armies, and in this case, I am having another child. It demands sacrifice from everyone. From me and from others. What is wrong with that?

exchanges.speaker: hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: What is wrong with it? When you speak of Isabel bearing another child... where is the shared sacrifice? Will you lie in that childbed? No. She will. And you call it sacrifice for your vision. Not our vision. Not even Castile's vision. Yours.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will not sit as long as you continue to stand. You stood up first, Fray. And I ask you to search your soul why you chose to do so.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando sits back down. He listens as Juan kneels and explains his definition of God's kingdom—protecting his daughter Catalina and all the 'Isabellas and Catalinas' of the world.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I kneel down as soon as Fray sits down. I think father that when I talk about my vision of God's kingdom, I mean how I think God's kingdom should look like. And I know that I can never achieve that... But I try anyway. When I think of all the Isabellas in the world... how can I do nothing? I cannot do nothing, Father. God's kingdom demands it from me.

exchanges.speaker: hernando_de_talavera
exchanges.text: I am not terrified of you, Your Majesty. I am terrified for you. You have constructed a perfect fortress of rationalization... You have learned to dress pride in humility and love. I cannot grant you absolution today. But I give you three questions to pray on.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will search my soul, Father, and these questions. I thank you for your patience.

encounters.recap: Juan's confession to Fray Hernando takes a devastating turn when the confessor identifies a dangerous pattern of messianic rationalization in Juan's thinking, denying absolution and assigning three soul-searching questions as penance.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Come and pray with me for a moment, Father Abbott. This sinner stands before God and would like some company. Then we can discuss these tiny worldly matters.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Gladly, Your Majesty. Domine Deus, in Te speramus. Illumina vias nostras. Non voluntas nostra, sed Tua fiat. Grant him wisdom to know the difference between Your call and his own ambition. Grant him courage to act when You command, and humility to wait when You counsel patience.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I remain kneeling for a moment. Forgive me Father. I cannot divide where my task as your instrument ends and my own greed and lust for glory starts. Grant me the wisdom and the patience to make this distinction. And please Father, I ask you to spare Isabel from a heavy delivery. You know there is not a more innocent soul in the world than she. Let me suffer instead Lord. Please... spare Isabel.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott remains kneeling beside Juan for another moment, then slowly rises.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... God hears the prayers of the humble. I cannot tell you whether He will spare Isabel... but I can tell you this: a king who kneels and begs to suffer in his wife's place is not the tyrant Fray Hernando fears. He is a man who loves. Come. Sit. Let us discuss Basel not as chess masters moving pieces, but as servants trying to discern what God asks of this moment.

encounters.recap: Juan and Abbott Rodrigo share a moment of prayer, asking God for wisdom and guidance, before preparing to discuss the Council's political landscape, closing the chapter with Fray Hernando's unanswered questions weighing heavily on Juan's soul.
